intro: Gagea thesioides, commonly known as the Sierra gagea, is a perennial bulbous plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its narrow, grass-like leaves and clusters of white or pale pink flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky, well-drained soils in open woodland or meadow habitats. Its bulbs are small and underground, serving as storage organs for nutrients. Gagea thesioides is adapted to dry summers and mild winters, making it a resilient component of its native ecosystem.
